title: How to Replace a Car Battery
description: Learn the essential steps to safely and correctly replace your car's battery, a common maintenance task that can save you time and money and prevent you from being stranded.
tools_required: New car battery (correct size for your vehicle)
Wrench set or socket set (10mm is common)
Battery terminal cleaner brush (or wire brush)

steps.title: Prepare Your Workspace and Put on Safety Gear
steps.description: Park your car on a flat, level surface, away from any open flames or sparks. Turn off the engine, engage the parking brake, and remove the key from the ignition. Open the hood and secure it with the prop rod. Before touching anything, put on your safety glasses and insulated gloves.
tips: Lay out your tools on a rag next to the work area to keep them organized and prevent them from getting lost in the engine bay.
Confirm your new battery matches the specifications, size, and terminal orientation of the old one before you begin.
warnings: Car batteries contain corrosive sulfuric acid and can release explosive hydrogen gas. Never smoke or create sparks near the battery.
Always wear eye protection and gloves to protect against acid splashes and electrical shock.
steps.image_prompt: A first-person point-of-view shot looking down at a collection of tools neatly arranged on a red shop rag next to the open hood of a modern sedan. The tools include a socket wrench set, a wire battery terminal brush, a can of anti-corrosion spray, safety glasses, and insulated gloves. The car is parked in a well-lit home garage. The lighting is bright and even, creating a clean, instructional feel. Photorealistic, high detail.

steps.title: Locate the Battery and Disconnect the Negative Terminal
steps.description: Locate the battery in the engine bay. Identify the negative (-) terminal, which is typically marked with a minus sign and has a black cable. Using the correct size wrench (usually 10mm), loosen the nut on the negative terminal clamp. You only need to loosen it enough to wiggle the cable off. Once loose, pull the cable clamp up and away from the battery post and tuck it to the side where it cannot accidentally touch the terminal again.
tips: If the clamp is stuck due to corrosion, gently twist it back and forth while pulling upwards. Do not use a metal tool to pry it off.
Some cars have a memory saver that plugs into the cigarette lighter to preserve radio presets. This is an optional tool for convenience.
warnings: ALWAYS disconnect the negative terminal first. This prevents accidental short circuits if your wrench touches a metal part of the car while working on the positive terminal.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up, over-the-shoulder shot showing a pair of hands wearing insulated gloves using a 10mm wrench to loosen the nut on the negative (-) battery terminal. The wrench is actively turning the nut. The negative cable is black. The background is the engine bay of a modern sedan in a well-lit garage. The focus is sharp on the tool and the terminal. Photorealistic, action shot.

steps.title: Disconnect the Positive Terminal
steps.description: Now, locate the positive (+) terminal, usually marked with a plus sign and a red cable, and often covered by a red plastic cap. Flip the cap open. Use your wrench to loosen the nut on the positive terminal clamp. Once loose, lift the cable clamp off the post and move it aside.
tips: Keep the positive and negative cables separate from each other and away from the battery posts.
warnings: Never allow a metal tool to touch both battery terminals simultaneously or to touch the positive terminal and a metal part of the car at the same time.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up, over-the-shoulder shot of hands in insulated gloves using a 10mm wrench to loosen the nut on the positive (+) battery terminal, which has a red plastic cover flipped open. The red positive cable is clearly visible. The already-disconnected black negative cable is tucked away to the side. The scene is in a well-lit garage. Photorealistic, high detail.

steps.title: Remove the Battery Hold-Down Bracket
steps.description: Locate the bracket or clamp that secures the battery in its tray. This is often a small metal bar at the base of the battery held by one or two long bolts. Use a socket wrench with an extension to reach and remove the bolts. Set the bracket and bolts aside in a safe place.
tips: A magnetic tray or a small container is useful for keeping track of small nuts and bolts so they don't get lost.
steps.image_prompt: A detailed shot focusing on a socket wrench with an extension being used by gloved hands to remove a bolt from the battery hold-down clamp at the base of the car battery. The battery terminals are disconnected and the cables are moved aside. The lighting clearly illuminates the bracket and the tool. The setting is a clean garage. Photorealistic.

steps.title: Remove the Old Battery and Clean the Tray
steps.description: With all connections and brackets removed, firmly grip the battery (many have a handle) and lift it straight up and out of the engine bay. Place it on the ground away from your work area. Inspect the battery tray and cable clamps for corrosion (a white or greenish powder). Use a battery terminal brush to scrub the clamps clean. You can neutralize any acid spills in the tray with a paste of baking soda and water, then wipe it clean and dry with a rag.
tips: Bend at your knees, not your back, when lifting. Car batteries are heavy, often weighing 30-50 lbs (14-23 kg).
warnings: Keep the old battery upright at all times to prevent corrosive acid from leaking out.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up macro shot of a gloved hand using a wire battery terminal cleaner brush to scrub the inside of a corroded battery cable clamp. The white, powdery corrosion is being brushed away from the lead clamp. In the background, the empty, clean battery tray is visible. The lighting is bright and focused on the cleaning action. Photorealistic, detailed.

steps.title: Install the New Battery and Secure It
steps.description: Carefully lower the new battery into the tray, ensuring the positive and negative terminals are oriented in the same position as the old one. Once the battery is seated flat, re-install the hold-down bracket. Tighten the bolts until the battery is snug and does not move when you push on it. Do not over-tighten, as this can crack the battery case.
warnings: Double-check the terminal orientation (+ and -). Installing a battery backwards can cause severe damage to your car's electrical system.
steps.image_prompt: A clear, instructional shot of a person's gloved hands carefully lowering a brand new, clean car battery into the empty battery tray in the engine bay. The red positive and black negative terminal markings on the new battery are clearly visible and correctly aligned with the car's cables. The setting is a bright, well-lit garage. Photorealistic.

steps.title: Reconnect Terminals and Apply Protector
steps.description: Now, reconnect the cables in the reverse order of removal. First, place the positive (+) cable clamp onto the positive terminal and tighten the nut with your wrench until it's snug. Close the red plastic cover. Next, connect the negative (-) cable clamp to the negative terminal and tighten it securely. To prevent future corrosion, spray a thin layer of anti-corrosion spray on both terminals.
tips: After tightening, try to gently twist each cable clamp. If it moves, it needs to be tightened a bit more for a solid connection.
If you don't have anti-corrosion spray, a thin layer of petroleum jelly will also work.
warnings: ALWAYS connect the positive terminal first, then the negative terminal last. This is the safest procedure to prevent sparks.
steps.image_prompt: An over-the-shoulder shot showing the final connection step. A gloved hand uses a 10mm wrench to tighten the black negative cable clamp onto the negative terminal. The red positive cable is already connected and secure. A can of anti-corrosion spray is visible on the fender, ready for the next action. The new battery looks clean in the well-lit engine bay. Photorealistic.

steps.title: Final Checks and Start the Car
steps.description: Give both battery cables a final gentle tug to ensure they are secure. Remove all of your tools and the rag from the engine bay. Close the hood securely. Get in the car and start the engine. It should start up normally. You may need to reset your car's clock and radio presets.
tips: Take your old battery back to the auto parts store where you bought the new one. They will recycle it properly and you will likely receive a refund for the 'core charge' that was included in the price of the new battery.
warnings: If the car's electronics act strangely, or if you see or smell smoke, turn the engine off immediately and re-check that your connections are clean and tight.
steps.image_prompt: A shot from the driver's seat, looking through the windshield into a home garage. The car's dashboard is brightly illuminated as the engine has just started successfully. The driver's hand is visible on the steering wheel. Outside, the closed hood of the car is visible. The scene conveys a sense of successful completion and satisfaction. Photorealistic, warm interior lighting.

safety_notes: Lead-acid batteries are heavy and contain hazardous materials. Always lift with your legs, not your back, and handle with care.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water after handling a car battery, even if you wore gloves.
Never lay a tool on top of the battery, as it could bridge the terminals and cause a dangerous short circuit.
Properly recycle your old battery. It is illegal and harmful to the environment to dispose of it in regular trash.
